reviews.text: I travel to Caracas often and stay at either the Tamanaco or the Marriott. Although I had one good stay at the Tamanaco last year, the rest were downhill and so the Marriott became my hotel of choice. On this trip, however, the hotel was sold out and so I opted for the Melia.
reviews.title: Best Hotel in Caracas

likes.liked: — Professional staff, proximity to shopping center

reviews.text: Although I'm one to walk out even when I've been advised not to, I was hesitant to stay at the Melia as I was repeatedly told the Sabana Grande neighborhood was seriously deteriorated and very unsafe.
reviews.title: Gran Melia tries to do well

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: When booking through their website, I had the option of a standard room for $189 and a deluxe room for $245. As it would fit my client's budget, I opted for the higher priced room and was very glad I did. I arrived at 2 p.m. and was told at the reception that no rooms were available. When I asked them to pre-check me in as I had to be at a meeting at 3, the staff member noticed the deluxe reservation and I was immediately taken to the 14th floor business lounge for check-in. My room, 1302, was spotless, a plate of fruit waiting my arrival, and full of amenities (controlling the a/c from bedside, e.g.). The television options were mind-boggling compared to other CCS hotels--I had 89 channels ranging from CNN to AlJezeera to Iran National TV to CCTV and all the Venezuelan channels (with many more in-between).
reviews.title: Horrible Staff at the Gran Melia Caracas

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I ordered room service for dinner and was very satisfied. Delivery was quick and professional, and the quality and taste of the food were very good. Their car service was also quick and efficient. Although it's not Starwood's "Heavenly Bed", I slept very comfortably. The business center staff was also extremely helpful.
reviews.title: a very good place
